quote: 150 miles in 8:28.42 on gravel was no small task. I reached new levels of pain and suffering that I have never experienced before... We established a small gap, and were soon joined by two riders who bridged across from the chasing group.
Rob and I were suffering hard. Working to keep team leader Bob out of the wind at every chance, we did our best until muscle cramps set in around the 100 mile mark.
I don't recall where I heard it, but someone over the weekend remarked there were 87 hills along the full 150-mile course...

Those 80-90-100ish miles were some of the hardest. The headwind, the rising heat... These miles are where you start chunking things… ride to the next checkpoint, the next turn, that tree in the distance, that rock on the ground...

Per my usual takes-forever-to-warm-up style, I let the super fast kids go, watched the sunrise, and found myself riding a nice steady 15mph pace to Checkpoint 1, which is just what happens when you heave your bike uphill at 10mph and fly downhill at 20-some mph over and over again, because this cour...

Those 80-90-100ish miles were some of the hardest. The headwind, the rising heat... Turn the corner and nothing but one long gravel road of giant rollers. Back into the headwind... Souls were crushed on that road.
Some riders finishing inside the top-10 of the Life Time Grand Prix (LTGP), the world's most prestigious off-road series, are barely breaking even, let alone earning a salary.
Gravel races forbid team tactics, which opens the door for more creativity and storytelling.

I was super confident in my wheel and tyre choice for this race, namely the Xentis Kappa2 650b 4-spoke carbon wheelset and WTB Resolute 650b x 42mm tyres. Both items were rolling fast and handled the loose stuff with ease.
Approximately 150 miles and near 10,000 ft of climbing – adventuring through the rural farmlands of Southeastern Nebraska.
Someone over the weekend remarked there were 87 hills along the full 150-mile course.

The roads were almost entirely hardpack and in great shape... The gravel roads were in primo condition although one had to be mindful of the deep sections of gravel that proliferated some parts of the course.
It's all rollers. A pirate-y rollercoaster as far as the eye can see. And corn. Lots of corn. More corn than I've ever seen in my life.

Turn the corner and nothing but one long gravel road of giant rollers. Back into the headwind... I passed a dude standing over his bike with his head on his handlebars. I yelled at that dude because we were literally three miles from the finish.
The lead group of 30 was averaging 21 mph, on loose gravel with rolling hills!

The real action of the day began at mile 30, when a super strong breakaway comprising Brian Jensen and Neil Shirley jumped clear. They would never be seen again. An believable effort for two men in those windy conditions!

Our four man squad was working hard into the strong winds, but it took a toll on Nate. He fell ill around the 75 mile mark and had to pull out of the race... Rob and I were suffering hard. Working to keep team leader Bob out of the wind at every chance.

Riding a 150-mile / 240 kilometre gravel race is about metering one's effort in doses, and mentally breaking up the race into small manageable chunks. My Garmin may have read '200-something kilometres until the finish', but I think about the distance between now and the next point of interest.

Per my usual takes-forever-to-warm-up style, I let the super fast kids go, watched the sunrise, and found myself riding a nice steady 15mph pace to Checkpoint 1, which is just what happens when you heave your bike uphill at 10mph and fly downhill at 20-some mph.

Those 80-90-100ish miles were some of the hardest. The headwind, the rising heat... These miles are where you start chunking things… ride to the next checkpoint, the next turn, that tree in the distance, that rock on the ground.

A very nice volunteer at Checkpoint 2 invited me to sit down, which I decided was a bad idea, but I did sip some Coke and spray some sunscreen over the portions of me which weren't covered with dirt. Then I bumbled my way out of there before any sitting down could happen because getting up is hard.
If an opportunity for a pickle presents itself, you should always take it.
Rob and I were suffering hard... we did our best until muscle cramps set in around the 100 mile mark. We bid farewell to Rob at round mile 110. He rolled the final 40 miles of the race solo.
Nathaniel... took a nasty spill into a ditch after losing it on a sharp and loose gravel corner
I passed a dude standing over his bike with his head on his handlebars... three miles from the finish.

I spent the last third of my seventh Solstice 100 in a bonked bewilderment. And I couldn't tell you why. Was I falling sick? Did the squishy roads zap more energy than I realized? Did I foul up my food? My pacing?

We started out as a group of friends who loved riding and just wanted to play bikes without all the rules. Like kids on a playground we made up our own rules together as we went and nicknamed each other the Pirate Cycling League.

The game has grown over the last decade to fit in all the people who want to come play. We have some rules now. We sometimes have to be the 'officials' but we are staying true to our roots and just want to have fun playing bikes. Some come to race some come to ride but we all share the same road.

The Pirate Cycling League was created to be a club for everyone... 'Pirate Cycling League was created from the desire to create community, ride bikes, have less rules and be more inclusive. It may sound simple now, but 15 years ago this was the opposite of most clubs out there.'
The PCL was and continues to be the club for those without a club, and lives by just one rule, 'Be cool'... The PCL has been focused on community since day one.
I'm an example of the byproduct of this incredible club. The first time I found community and ultimately fell in love with cycling was because of the Pirate Cycling League.

There were chairs in shade and ice towels... Schillingbridge Tap House is at the finish line. Pizzas and chips and salsa were ordered... The awards ceremony was pretty well-attended, particularly since it can be viewed from the bar patio...
A newly formed $15,000 donation based prize pool that is the first of its kind at a major gravel race.

The result is more than $100,000 raised through Gravel Worlds and other PCL events. One such event is the 100% fundraising event, 'Randy's Ride' which celebrates the life and legacy of Randy Gibson, a Gravel Worlds promoter and cyclist who was killed by a drunk driver in 2017.
Gravel Worlds had now become a staple of the gravel scene... this event and Barry-Roubaix are really the only gravel events which can trace an unbroken line from before 2010 to the present day.

In keeping with PCL tradition and mission statement, there will be no entry fee. Riders will be required to purchase Nebraska Lottery Powerball tickets as proof of reaching a checkpoint (date and time are indicated on the ticket).
